pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:0.5: 31. The training rule on alms-meals at public guesthouses
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.2: a certain association was preparing an alms-meal at a public guesthouse not far from Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.3: Then, after robing up in the morning, the monks from the group of six took their bowls and robes and entered Sāvatthī for alms. Not getting anything, they went to that public guesthouse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.4: Because it was a long time since they had been there, people served them respectfully.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.5: A second and a third day those monks did the same thing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.7: “What’s the point of returning to the monastery?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.8: Tomorrow we’ll just have to come back here.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.9: So they stayed on and on right there, eating alms at the guesthouse,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.10: while the monastics of other religions left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.12: “How can the Sakyan monastics stay on and on, eating alms at the guesthouse?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.13: We don’t prepare the alms-food just for them;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.15: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.16: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.17: “How could the monks from the group of six stay on and on, eating alms at a public guesthouse?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.18: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.21: “Foolish men, how could you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.23: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.24.1: ‘If a monk eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:1.25: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.1: Soon afterwards Venerable Sāriputta was traveling through the Kosalan country on his way to Sāvatthī when he came to a public guesthouse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.2: Because it was a long time since he had been there, people served him respectfully.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.3: After he had eaten, Sāriputta became severely ill, and he was unable to leave that guesthouse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.4: On the second day, too, those people said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.7: the Buddha had prohibited eating alms at a public guesthouse after staying on and on, and because he was afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.8: As a consequence, he missed his meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.9: When he arrived at Sāvatthī, he told the monks what had happened,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.10: and they in turn told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.11: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.12: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to stay on at a public guesthouse and eat alms there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.13: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:2.14.1: ‘If a monk who is not sick eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.2: he is able to leave that public guesthouse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.4: he is unable to leave that public guesthouse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.6: as much as one needs of any of the five cooked foods, prepared for the general public, in a building, under a roof cover, at the foot of a tree, or out in the open.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.7: A monk who is not sick may eat there once. If he receives food beyond that with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.1.8: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.1: If he is not sick, and he perceives himself as not sick, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.2: If he is not sick, but he is unsure of it, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.3: If he is not sick, but he perceives himself as sick, and he eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.4: If he is sick, but he perceives himself as not sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.5: If he is sick, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.2.6: If he is sick, and he perceives himself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.3: if he is not sick and he eats once;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.4: if he eats while coming or going;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.5: if he eats after being invited by the owners;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.6: if the food is prepared specifically for him;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.7: if there is not as much as he needs;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.8: if it is anything apart from the five cooked foods;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc31:3.3.11: The training rule on alms-meals at public guesthouses, the first, is finished.
